required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Tailored Approaches to Stroke Health Education
clinical_study.official_title: Tailored Approaches to Stroke Health Education

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS)

brief_summary.textblock: The overarching goal of the proposed intervention is to reduce stroke disparities by overcoming pre-hospital barriers related to emergency stroke treatment and facilitating the appropriate response to acute stroke using a novel culturally-tailored and sustainable approach developed by an experienced transdisciplinary team. Building on our previous work, in which the investigators have identified barriers to increasing stroke literacy and behavioral intent to call 911, the investigators will develop and evaluate the effectiveness of a novel, culturally tailored intervention using storytelling (narrative persuasion) in the form of two professionally produced 12-minute films (in English and Spanish), in minority populations in New York City (NYC). Behavioral intent to call 911 will be assessed immediately after viewing the film, 6 months later, and one year later.

detailed_description.textblock: Stroke is the leading cause of adult disability and costs U.S. taxpayers >$60 billion annually. Interventions designed to educate patients to seek treatment sooner when a stroke occurs may increase low rates of treatment with thrombolysis (current rates 3% national average). Thrombolysis can increase the odds of minimal to zero disability from stroke if emergency medical system response times and in-hospital response times are optimized (maximum time from symptom onset to intravenous thrombolysis is 4.5 hours). Black and Hispanic Americans have higher stroke incidence compared to Whites and are less likely to receive thrombolysis for acute stroke. The latency to hospital arrival is largely dependent on patients' recognition of stroke symptoms, and immediate presentation to the emergency department. The investigators have found very low stroke literacy rates among Blacks and Hispanics compared to Whites, which may, in part, be responsible for disparities in acute stroke treatment.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Within one hour of stroke education intervention.
primary_outcome.description: The Stroke Action Test (STAT) contains 21 items that name or describe stroke symptoms from all 5 groups of warning signs and 7 items that are nonstroke symptoms. For each item, the respondent selects 1 of 4 options: call 911, call doctor, wait 1 hour, or wait 1 day. For scoring purposes, each correct response receives 1 point; incorrect responses receive 0 points. The total score is reported as percent of correct responses. Scores range from 0% to 100% with a higher score indicating a better outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within six months of stroke education intervention.
secondary_outcome.description: The Stroke Action Test (STAT) contains 21 items that name or describe stroke symptoms from all 5 groups of warning signs and 7 items that are nonstroke symptoms. For each item, the respondent selects 1 of 4 options: call 911, call doctor, wait 1 hour, or wait 1 day. For scoring purposes, each correct response receives 1 point; incorrect responses receive 0 points. The total score is reported as percent of correct responses. Scores range from 0% to 100% with a higher score indicating a better outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within one year of stroke education intervention.
secondary_outcome.description: The Stroke Action Test (STAT) contains 21 items that name or describe stroke symptoms from all 5 groups of warning signs and 7 items that are nonstroke symptoms. For each item, the respondent selects 1 of 4 options: call 911, call doctor, wait 1 hour, or wait 1 day. For scoring purposes, each correct response receives 1 point; incorrect responses receive 0 points. The total score is reported as percent of correct responses. Scores range from 0% to 100% with a higher score indicating a better outcome.

other_outcome.measure: Time to emergency room after suffering a stroke
other_outcome.description: This measures the time in getting to the emergency room after having suffered a stroke.

arm_group.description: Participants will receive education through a novel program called Stroke Education Film Viewing.
Participants will receive education through Stroke Education Pamphlet Exposure.

intervention.description: A novel, culturally tailored intervention using storytelling (narrative persuasion) in the form of two professionally produced 12-min films (in English and Spanish), in minority populations in New York City.
"Usual Care": Stroke Education pamphlet and brochure distribution.

facility.name: Columbia University Medical Center, Neurological Institute

responsible_party.investigator_title: Chief of Staff of Neurology Associate Professor of Clinical Neurology
